fr:title.text: A functorial theory of judgments and deductions

fr:frontmatter.fr:title: A functorial theory of judgments and deductions

fr:mainmatter.fr:p:
This is my attempt at a general theory of judgments and deductions, based on Greta Coraglia's and Ivan Di Liberti's paper, Context, Judgement, Deduction.
Start at .
A deductive theory \mathcal {T} is a small strict 2-category with all finite 2-limits. We call the objects of \mathcal {T} judgements, the 1-cells rules, and the 2-cells policies.

From the existence of 2-limits, we have for each judgement \mathcal {J} in \mathcal {T} a corresponding judgement \mathcal {J}^\to of "arrows" in \mathcal {J}. If for example \mathcal {J} is supposed to be a judgement for contexts a la type theory, then \mathcal {J}^\to is a judgment of substitutions between contexts, with the rule \mathrm {dom} : \mathcal {J}^\to \to \mathcal {J} saying that the domain is a context and the rule \mathrm {cod} : \mathcal {J}^\to \to \mathcal {J} saying that the codomain is a context. That \mathrm {dom} is an fibration says that it is stable under substitutions contravariantly, and dually for cod.
A model of a deductive theory \mathcal {T} is a 2-limit (and fibration) preserving 2-functor \mathcal {T} \to \mathbf {Cat}.
Asking for a rule to be a fibration is asking that it be stable under substitution in the base.

As an example, consider the deductive theory \mathcal {T}_\mathrm {dtt} generated by a fibration \mathbf {ctx} \to 1 and discrete fibrations \mathcal {U}, \dot {\mathcal {U}} \to \mathbf {ctx}, as well as a map of fibrations \Sigma : \dot {\mathcal {U}} \to \mathcal {U}, such that \mathbf {ctx} \to 1 and \Sigma have a right adjoint.
A model \mathcal {A} of \mathcal {T}_\mathrm {dtt} then consists of a category \mathbf {ctx}^\mathcal {A} with a terminal objects, as well as two discrete fibrations \mathcal {U}^\mathcal {A}, \dot {\mathcal {U}}^\mathcal {A} over \mathbf {ctx}^A and a map of fibrations \Sigma : \mathcal {U}^\mathcal {A} \to \dot {\mathcal {U}}^\mathcal {A} with a right adjoint. Thus this corresponds to a natural model a la Awodey.
